contentrichtext.text: '''Jupiter Cantab Limited''' was a [[Cambridge]] based [[home computer]] company. Its main product was the 1983 [[Forth (programming language)|Forth]] based [[Jupiter Ace]]. The company was founded in 1982 by two ex-[[Sinclair Research]] staffers, [[Richard Altwasser]] and [[Steve Vickers (academia)|Steven Vickers]]. Their machine was, externally, remarkably similar to the [[ZX Spectrum]], with a copycat rubber keyboard. It also used the same [[Zilog Z80|Z80]] processor. However, the Ace's video output was limited to monochrome, unlike the Spectrum's 8 colour capability. The Â£90 Ace was a flop in both the UK and US markets: the Forth language, although considered powerful, was not as popular or accessible as the already well-established BASIC language featured in competing microcomputers. In the US it was sold as the ''Ace 4000''. The company went bankrupt in November 1983 and its assets were sold to [[Boldfield Computing|Boldfield Computing Ltd]] in 1984.
